channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: In Pictures: Remembering Susan Stamberg, one of NPR's Founding Mothers
item.description: Susan Stamberg joined NPR at its start, originally to cut tape — literal tape, with a single-sided blade — at a time when commercial networks almost never hired women.
item.content:encoded:
Susan Stamberg joined NPR at its start, originally to cut tape — literal tape, with a single-sided blade — at a time when commercial networks almost never hired women.

(Image credit: Jay Kernis)
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: Ex-national security adviser John Bolton indicted in classified documents case
item.description: The charges come two months after the FBI executed a search warrant at Bolton's suburban Washington home.
item.content:encoded:
The charges come two months after the FBI executed a search warrant at Bolton's suburban Washington home.

(Image credit: Logan Cyrus)
item.dc:creator: NPR Washington Desk

item.title: Adelita Grijalva can force a vote on the Epstein files, but she's still not sworn in
item.description: The Arizona Democrat would be the decisive signature on a petition to force a vote on releasing the records. But Speaker Mike Johnson says he will not swear her in until after the shutdown is over.
item.content:encoded:
The Arizona Democrat would be the decisive signature on a petition to force a vote on releasing the records. But Speaker Mike Johnson says he will not swear her in until after the shutdown is over.

(Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)
item.dc:creator: Claudia Grisales

item.title: NPR 'founding mother' Susan Stamberg has died
item.description: Susan Stamberg, an original National Public Radio staffer who went on to become the first U.S. woman to anchor a nightly national news program, has died.
item.content:encoded:
Susan Stamberg, an original National Public Radio staffer who went on to become the first U.S. woman to anchor a nightly national news program, has died.

(Image credit: Michael Tran)
item.dc:creator: David Folkenflik

item.title: President Trump envisions D.C. arch to mark 250th anniversary of U.S.
item.description: On Wednesday, the president showcased models for a grand new monument to be added to the gateway of the National Mall: a large, neoclassical arch topped with eagles and a gilded, winged figure.
item.content:encoded:
On Wednesday, the president showcased models for a grand new monument to be added to the gateway of the National Mall: a large, neoclassical arch topped with eagles and a gilded, winged figure.

(Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: Trump says he plans to meet Putin again as Ukraine war drags
item.description: President Trump says he will meet with the Russia president in Budapest, after high level meetings next week that would include Secretary of State Marco Rubio.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump says he will meet with the Russia president in Budapest, after high level meetings next week that would include Secretary of State Marco Rubio.

(Image credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds)
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: At least 27 states turned over sensitive data about food stamp recipients to USDA
item.description: Democratic-led states secured a legal victory to keep the personal data of food recipients out of the federal government's reach. But NPR's reporting shows that millions of records on Americans have already been shared.
item.content:encoded:
Democratic-led states secured a legal victory to keep the personal data of food recipients out of the federal government's reach. But NPR's reporting shows that millions of records on Americans have already been shared.

(Image credit: Frederic J. Brown)
item.dc:creator: Jude Joffe-Block

item.title: A study found lead in popular protein powders. Here's why you shouldn't panic
item.description: Consumer Reports expressed concern about high levels of lead in some two dozen protein powders, but only with repeated high exposure. Here's what to know before you make your next grocery run.
item.content:encoded:
Consumer Reports expressed concern about high levels of lead in some two dozen protein powders, but only with repeated high exposure. Here's what to know before you make your next grocery run.

(Image credit: Tatiana/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Some of the things Gaza needs: A government, security and tools to rebuild
item.description: A shaky ceasefire is holding. Now the Palestinian territory is in urgent need of a functioning government, order on the streets, and resources to start rebuilding the shattered territory.
item.content:encoded:
A shaky ceasefire is holding. Now the Palestinian territory is in urgent need of a functioning government, order on the streets, and resources to start rebuilding the shattered territory.

(Image credit: Abood Abusalama)
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Trump escalates pressure on Venezuelan drug trade. And, judge pauses shutdown layoffs
item.description: Trump escalates pressure on Venezuela by authorizing covert CIA operations. And, a federal judge halts the Trump administration's shutdown layoffs.
item.content:encoded:
Trump escalates pressure on Venezuela by authorizing covert CIA operations. And, a federal judge halts the Trump administration's shutdown layoffs.

(Image credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton
